Client Selection for Federated Bayesian Learning

Jiarong Yang, Yuan Liu, and Rahif Kassab This work was supported in part by the Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61971196, Grant U1701265, and Grant U2001210. (Corresponding author: Yuan Liu.) J. Yang and Y. Liu are with school of Electronic and Information Engineering, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510641, China (e-mails: eejiarong@mail.scut.edu.cn, eeyliu@scut.edu.cn). Rahif Kassab is with the King’s Communications, Learning and Information Processing (KCLIP) Lab King’s College London, London WC2B4BG, U.K. (email: rahif.kassab@kcl.ac.uk).
Abstract

Distributed Stein Variational Gradient Descent (DSVGD) is a non-parametric distributed learning framework for federated Bayesian learning, where multiple clients jointly train a machine learning model by communicating a number of non-random and interacting particles with the server. Since communication resources are limited, selecting the clients with most informative local learning updates can improve the model convergence and communication efficiency. In this paper, we propose two selection schemes for DSVGD based on Kernelized Stein Discrepancy (KSD) and Hilbert Inner Product (HIP). We derive the upper bound on the decrease of the global free energy per iteration for both schemes, which is then minimized to speed up the model convergence. We evaluate and compare our schemes with conventional schemes in terms of model accuracy, convergence speed, and stability using various learning tasks and datasets.

Index Terms:
Federated Bayesian learning, scheduling, client selection, variational inference.

I Introduction

The rapid development of machine learning has impacted various aspects of today’s society, from autonomous vehicles to computer vision, bioscience and natural language processing [1]. Conventionally, training machine learning models relies on the availability of big datasets at a centralized remote location, e.g., a central server, where training is carried out. However, most data is generated in a distributed fashion, e.g., by edge devices/clients, and thus needs to be collected at the central server to enable training. With the increasing awareness for data security and privacy, uploading local data to a remote location is no longer a viable solution. To cope with this challenge, federated learning [2, 3, 4] was proposed as a distributed learning framework that performs model training at the client side using the client’s local dataset and then shares the client’s model with the server, where various models are aggregated. Thus, under this framework, the client’s data is preserved on their device. In some practical scenarios, such as medical diagnosis and autonomous driving, models need to provide not only predictions but also a calibrated confidence measure that reflects the amount by which the client can trust a given prediction. However, most federated learning algorithms are based on frequentist learning principle which is known to be unable to quantify epistemic uncertainty, yielding overconfident decisions [5, 6]. In contrast, Bayesian learning is more suitable in such scenarios as it provides a more accurate estimate of uncertainty by optimizing over the space of distributions of model parameters instead of a single vector of model parameters [7, 8].

The main goal of federated Bayesian learning is to train a global posterior by clients which exchange model parameters with a central server over a wireless channel [9, 10, 11]. Therefore, the convergence of the model is often affected by the number of communication rounds [12, 13] and data-heterogeneity [14, 15]. Specifically, on one hand, model training requires frequent exchanges of model parameters between the server and clients over a channel, so a large number of communication resources (i.e., time and frequency resources) will cause large communication delays, which in turn affects the convergence speed of the model. On the other hand, clients are isolated from each other, consequently, there is no guarantee that the data between clients is independent and identically distributed (IID). Such heterogeneity of client’s data will reduce the model accuracy and slow down the convergence speed. Therefore, it is concluded that local learning updates of distributed clients do not contribute equally to global model convergence [16, 17, 18]. A promising technique to tackle this issue is scheduling or client selection, i.e., select the clients with most informative data for participation so as to not only accelerate the learning process but also reduce communication overhead.

I-A Prior Work

Existing federated Bayesian learning techniques can be classified to two families: Monte Carlo (MC) sampling or Variational Inference (VI). MC-based federated Bayesian learning[19, 20] such as Distributed Stochastic Gradient Langevin Dynamics (DSGLD), maintains a number of Markov chains that are updated via local Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) and injects noise into the parameter updates [21, 19]. Unfortunately, the model convergence for such techniques is difficult to assess and the convergence speed is low. VI-based federated Bayesian learning [22, 11, 10, 23] such as Partitioned Variational Inference (PVI) optimizes over parametric posteriors from tractable families (e.g., the exponential family) using natural gradient descent [10]. However, limiting the optimization to tractable families incurs bias. Accordingly, Distributed Stein Variational Gradient Descent (DSVGD) has been proposed as a method to eliminate such bias by encoding the variational posterior with deterministic particles that are updated by each scheduled client using Stein Variational Gradient Descent (SVGD) [24]. When the number of particles is large enough, any posterior could be approximated. By tuning the number of particles, DSVGD can trade off bias, convergence speed and per-iteration complexity [23]. More details on SVGD and DSVGD are given in Section II.

One of the biggest challenges in federated learning is decreasing the communication load. This challenge, known as communication-efficient federated learning, recently received lots of interest in the wireless research community. More specifically, multiple techniques have been studied to decrease the communication load, for e.g., through the joint design of learning and communication such as learning update compression [25, 26], radio resource management [27, 28, 29] and over-the-air computation [30, 31, 32]. Another technique, often referred to as client selection or scheduling, exploits the difference in the clients’ model updates and selects the clients with the most informative updates in order to increase the convergence speed while decreasing the total communication load [16, 33, 34, 35]. For example, authors of [34] use gradient divergence to quantify the importance of each local update, and propose a novel importance and channel-aware scheduling policy. In [35], the inner product between each local gradient and the ground-truth global gradient is used to quantify the importance of data, and a fast convergent algorithm is proposed where the local update is weighted by the the inner product.

Most of the existing schemes considered in the literature are applicable to frequentist federated learning. In this paper, we explore the benefits of client selection for federated Bayesian learning. More specifically, we consider DSVGD [23], which is a non-parametric distributed variational inference framework for federated Bayesian learning. DSVGD uses a number of non-random and interacting particles to represent the variational posterior distribution of the model’s parameters. The particles are updated iteratively by each scheduled client using SVGD [24]. We propose and analyze two client selection approaches for DSVGD that lead to faster convergence and lower communication cost.

I-B Contributions

In this paper, we propose two selection schemes for DSVGD based on the Kernelized Stein Discrepancy (KSD) [36] and the Hilbert Inner Product (HIP) [37] for federated Bayesian learning. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We first propose a client selection scheme based on the KSD between the global posterior and the local tilted distribution. The client with a larger KSD will have a higher probability of being selected since it provides updates that maximize the decrease of the local free energy per iteration.

  • •

    We also propose a scheme based on the HIP between the SVGD update function for the global and local likelihood. We derive the closed form of HIP using the properties of the Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS). The larger the HIP the higher the probability of a client being selected per iteration.

  • •

    For both schemes, we derive the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy between any two consecutive iterations. It is revealed that both schemes improve the model convergence, where the KSD-based scheme has smaller communication overhead, but the HIP-based scheme has faster convergence.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the federated Bayesian learning framework and DSVGD. Section III proposes two client selection schemes and the corresponding convergence analysis. Section IV provides experimental results, followed by conclusions in Section V.

II System Model and Preliminaries

In this section, we first describe the considered system model and then introduce the technical preliminaries used in our paper. The key notations that are important for the system model and the technical preliminaries are summarized in Table I.

II-A Federated Bayesian Learning

As shown in Fig. 1, we consider a system setup for federated Bayesian learning[9], where a central server maintains the variational global posterior distribution q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) where θ𝜃\theta is the model parameter vector, for e.g., weights of a neural network. Furthermore, K𝐾K clients, based on their local dataset Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k}, exchange their own view of the variational posterior q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) with the server. Following the Bayesian learning framework [38], the goal is to minimize the global free energy over the space of distributions as:

minq​(θ){F(q(θ))=∑k=1K𝔼θ∼q​(θ)[Lk(θ)]+αKL(q(θ)∥p0(θ))},\displaystyle\min_{q(\theta)}\left\{F(q(\theta))=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q(\theta)}[L_{k}(\theta)]+\alpha\mathrm{KL}(q(\theta)\rVert p_{0}(\theta))\right\}, (1)

where Lk​(θ)subscript𝐿𝑘𝜃L_{k}(\theta) is the local training loss for model parameter θ𝜃\theta. The global free energy reflects a trade-off between the sum loss function over all clients data and the complexity defined by the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) and known prior distribution p0​(θ)subscript𝑝0𝜃p_{0}(\theta). The trade-off the two terms is dictated by the temperature level α𝛼\alpha. Using simple algebraic manipulations, the global free energy in (1) can re-written as

minq​(θ){F(q(θ))=αKL(q(θ)∥q~o​p​t(θ))},\displaystyle\min_{q(\theta)}\left\{F(q(\theta))=\alpha\mathrm{KL}(q(\theta)\rVert\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta))\right\}, (2)

where q~o​p​t​(θ)subscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta) is the unnormalized optimal global posterior define as

q~o​p​t=p0​(θ)​∏k=1Kpk​(θ),subscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡subscript𝑝0𝜃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃\displaystyle\tilde{q}_{opt}=p_{0}(\theta)\prod_{k=1}^{K}p_{k}(\theta), (3)

where p0​(θ)subscript𝑝0𝜃p_{0}(\theta) is the prior distribution and pk​(θ)subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃p_{k}(\theta) is the local likelihood at client k𝑘k defined as pk​(θ)=exp⁡(−α−1​Lk​(θ))subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃superscript𝛼1subscript𝐿𝑘𝜃p_{k}(\theta)=\exp(-\alpha^{-1}L_{k}(\theta)). (2) shows visually the optimization target of the variational inference. Specifically, Bayesian inference aims to obtain the posterior distribution, which is generally referred to as the target distribution, over the model parameters. Variational inference uses KL divergence to measure the similarity between two distributions and frames the Bayesian inference problem into a deterministic optimization that approximates the target distribution with a simpler distribution by minimizing their KL divergence. Therefore, global free energy refers to the KL divergence to be optimized in the variational inference, which is the KL divergence between the variational global posterior q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) and the optimal global posterior q~o​p​t​(θ)subscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta), as shown in (2). By normalizing q~o​p​t​(θ)subscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta) with the normalization constant Z𝑍Z as qo​p​t​(θ)=q~o​p​t​(θ)Zsubscript𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃subscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃𝑍q_{opt}(\theta)=\frac{\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta)}{Z} and setting q​(θ)=qo​p​t​(θ)∝q~o​p​t​(θ)𝑞𝜃subscript𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃proportional-tosubscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃q(\theta)=q_{opt}(\theta)\propto\tilde{q}_{opt}(\theta), the global free energy can be minimized. However, this is not possible for two main reasons: first, computing qo​p​t​(θ)subscript𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡𝜃q_{opt}(\theta) requires the normalization constant Z𝑍Z which involves computing a multidimensional integral and thus is not feasible in practice. Second, from (3) and the definition of pk​(θ)subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃p_{k}(\theta), computing q~o​p​tsubscript~𝑞𝑜𝑝𝑡\tilde{q}_{opt} requires access to all datasets of the K𝐾K clients in order to compute pk​(θ)subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃p_{k}(\theta).

Following the federated Bayesian learning framework in [23], we restrict q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) to the family of distributions having the following form:

q​(θ)=p0​(θ)​∏k=1Ktk​(θ).𝑞𝜃subscript𝑝0𝜃superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑡𝑘𝜃\displaystyle q(\theta)=p_{0}(\theta)\prod_{k=1}^{K}t_{k}(\theta). (4)

The global free energy minimization is then conducted in a distributed manner minimizing the local free energy at each selected client as

minq​(θ){Fk(q(θ))=αKL(q(θ)∥p~k(θ))},\displaystyle\min_{q(\theta)}\left\{F_{k}(q(\theta))=\alpha\mathrm{KL}(q(\theta)\rVert\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta))\right\}, (5)

where

p~k​(θ)=q​(θ)tk​(θ)⋅pk​(θ)subscript~𝑝𝑘𝜃⋅𝑞𝜃subscript𝑡𝑘𝜃subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃\displaystyle\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta)=\frac{q(\theta)}{t_{k}(\theta)}\cdot p_{k}(\theta) (6)

is the local tilted distribution and tk​(θ)subscript𝑡𝑘𝜃t_{k}(\theta) approximates the scaled local likelihood pkZksubscript𝑝𝑘subscript𝑍𝑘\frac{p_{k}}{Z_{k}} where Z=∏k=1KZk𝑍superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑍𝑘Z=\prod_{k=1}^{K}Z_{k}. It is shown in [10] that minimizing the local free energies (5) across all clients leads to the minimum of the global free energy in (2) by suitably combining the local energies minimums. Note that the clients contribute differently to the decrease of the global free energy, which can be accelerated by preferentially selecting clients with higher contribution. By definition of q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) in (4), the tilted distribution p~ksubscript~𝑝𝑘\tilde{p}_{k} in (6), the tilted distribution p~ksubscript~𝑝𝑘\tilde{p}_{k} contains the true likelihood pk​(θ)subscript𝑝𝑘𝜃p_{k}(\theta) of client k𝑘k and the approximate scaled likelihoods tk′superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘′t_{k}^{\prime} for k′≠ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}\neq k, of the remaining clients. Once the local free energy minimization problem in (5) is solved by the selected client k𝑘k at iteration i𝑖i, a new global variational posterior q(i)​(θ)superscript𝑞𝑖𝜃q^{(i)}(\theta) is obtained and the approximate scaled local likelihood is updated as

tk(i)=q(i)​(θ)q(i−1)​(θ)​tk(i−1)​(θ),superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖superscript𝑞𝑖𝜃superscript𝑞𝑖1𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖1𝜃\displaystyle t_{k}^{(i)}=\frac{q^{(i)}(\theta)}{q^{(i-1)}(\theta)}t_{k}^{(i-1)}(\theta), (7)

for each selected client k𝑘k, while tk′(i)​(θ)=tk′(i−1)​(θ)superscriptsubscript𝑡superscript𝑘′𝑖𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑡superscript𝑘′𝑖1𝜃t_{k^{\prime}}^{(i)}(\theta)=t_{k^{\prime}}^{(i-1)}(\theta) for clients k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime} that are not selected.

To summarize, the general process of federated Bayesian learning is as follows:

  • •

    Step 1: The server serially selects a client and sends the current variational global posterior q(i−1)superscript𝑞𝑖1q^{(i-1)} to the selected client.

  • •

    Step 2: The selected client minimizes the local free energy in (5) to obtain the current variational global posterior q(i)​(θ)superscript𝑞𝑖𝜃q^{(i)}(\theta).

  • •

    Step 3: The updated variational global posterior q(i)​(θ)superscript𝑞𝑖𝜃q^{(i)}(\theta) is uploaded to the server and the approximate scaled local likelihood is updated using (7) at the client side.

  • •

    Step 4: The server updates the current variational global posterior by setting q(i−1)​(θ)⟵q(i)​(θ)⟵superscript𝑞𝑖1𝜃superscript𝑞𝑖𝜃q^{(i-1)}(\theta)\longleftarrow q^{(i)}(\theta) and continues to serially select the next client.

II-B Preliminaries

In this paper, we investigate the client selection problem in DSVGD, which is a novel federated Bayesian learning framework and applies SVGD to the federated Bayesian learning framework presented in Section II-A to solve the local free energy in (5). Next, we illustrate the preliminaries of KSD, SVGD, and DSVGD that are used in our algorithms.

II-B1 Kernel Stein Discrepancy

We start by introducing two important definitions in the Stein’s method, namely the Stein’s operator and the Stein’s identity. Stein’s operator is defined as 𝒜p​𝒇​(θ)=[∇log⁡p​(θ)​𝒇​(θ)⊤+∇𝒇​(θ)]subscript𝒜𝑝𝒇𝜃delimited-[]∇𝑝𝜃𝒇superscript𝜃top∇𝒇𝜃\mathcal{A}_{p}\bm{f}(\theta)=[\nabla\log p(\theta)\bm{f}(\theta)^{\top}+\nabla\bm{f}(\theta)], where p​(θ)𝑝𝜃p(\theta) is a smooth density and 𝒇=[f1​(θ),…,fd​(θ)]⊤𝒇superscriptsubscript𝑓1𝜃…subscript𝑓𝑑𝜃top\bm{f}=[f_{1}(\theta),...,f_{d}(\theta)]^{\top}is a smooth vector function. While Stein’s identity can be written as 𝔼θ∼p​[𝒜p​𝒇​(θ)]=0subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝒜𝑝𝒇𝜃0\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim p}[\mathcal{A}_{p}\bm{f}(\theta)]=0, it is generally used to measure the divergence between two distributions. Given two distributions p​(θ)𝑝𝜃p(\theta) and q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) where q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) is possibly unnormalized, the divergence is defined as the maximum of the expectation for trace of the Stein’s operator 𝒜q​𝒇​(θ)subscript𝒜𝑞𝒇𝜃\mathcal{A}_{q}\bm{f}(\theta) under θ∼p​(θ)similar-to𝜃𝑝𝜃\theta\sim p(\theta) as

𝔻​(p,q)=max𝒇∈ℋd⁡{𝔼θ∼p​[trace​(𝒜q​𝒇​(θ))]},𝔻𝑝𝑞subscript𝒇superscriptℋ𝑑subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑝delimited-[]tracesubscript𝒜𝑞𝒇𝜃\displaystyle\mathbb{D}(p,q)=\max_{\bm{f}\in\mathcal{H}^{d}}\{\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim p}[\mathrm{trace}(\mathcal{A}_{q}\bm{f}(\theta))]\}, (8)

where 𝒇𝒇\bm{f} is restricted to lie within the unit ball of a RKHS ℋdsuperscriptℋ𝑑\mathcal{H}^{d} defined by a positive definite kernel k​(θ,θ′)k𝜃superscript𝜃′\mathrm{k}(\theta,\theta^{\prime}). According to [24], we can rewrite (8) using the properties of RKHS as

𝔻(p,q)=max𝒇∈ℋd{⟨𝒇,ϕ∗⟩ℋd,s.t.∥ϕ∗∥ℋd≤1},\displaystyle\mathbb{D}(p,q)=\max_{\bm{f}\in\mathcal{H}^{d}}\{\langle\bm{f},\phi^{*}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}},\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ s.t.\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \|\phi^{*}\|_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}\leq 1\}, (9)

where ϕ∗​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼p​[∇log⁡q​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]superscriptitalic-ϕ⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑝delimited-[]∇𝑞𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi^{*}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim p}[\nabla\log q(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)]. According to the properties of the inner product, the maximum value of ⟨𝒇,ϕ∗⟩ℋdsubscript𝒇superscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑\langle\bm{f},\phi^{*}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} is obtained as ‖ϕ∗‖ℋdsubscriptnormsuperscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑\|\phi^{*}\|_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} when 𝒇𝒇\bm{f} is in the same direction as ϕ∗superscriptitalic-ϕ\phi^{*}. In [36], the KSD is defined as the square of this maximum value:

𝕊​(p,q)=‖ϕ∗‖ℋd2.𝕊𝑝𝑞superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑2\displaystyle\mathbb{S}(p,q)=\|\phi^{*}\|_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}^{2}. (10)

II-B2 Stein Variational Gradient Descent

SVGD [24] is a non-parametric variational inference algorithm that aims to solve optimization problems of a similar form to (5). SVGD encodes the variational distribution q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) using a set of particles {θn}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} that are updated iteratively to match the (unnormalized) target distribution p~​(θ)~𝑝𝜃\tilde{p}(\theta) as

θn[l]←←superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛delimited-[]𝑙absent\displaystyle\theta_{n}^{[l]}\leftarrow θn[l−1]+ϵ​ϕ​(θn[l−1]),superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛delimited-[]𝑙1italic-ϵitalic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛delimited-[]𝑙1\displaystyle\theta_{n}^{[l-1]}+\epsilon\phi(\theta_{n}^{[l-1]}), (11)

where the SVGD update function ϕ​(⋅)italic-ϕ⋅\phi(\cdot) is optimized to maximize the steepest descent decrease of the KL divergence between q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) and the target distribution p~​(θ)~𝑝𝜃\tilde{p}(\theta) as follows

ϕ(⋅)=arg⁡maxϕ​(⋅)∈ℋd{−dd​ϵ\displaystyle\phi(\cdot)=\mathop{\arg\max}_{\phi(\cdot)\in\mathcal{H}^{d}}\bigg{\{}-\frac{d}{d\epsilon} KL​(q​(θ)∥p~​(θ))KLconditional𝑞𝜃~𝑝𝜃\displaystyle\mathrm{KL}(q(\theta)\|\tilde{p}(\theta))
=𝔼θ∼q[trace(𝒜p~ϕ(θ))]}.\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\mathrm{trace}(\mathcal{A}_{\tilde{p}}\phi(\theta))]\bigg{\}}. (12)

As shown in (II-B2), the negative gradient of the KL divergence has the same form as KSD, so we can rewrite the term 𝔼θ∼q​[trace​(𝒜p~​ϕ​(θ))]subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]tracesubscript𝒜~𝑝italic-ϕ𝜃\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\mathrm{trace}(\mathcal{A}_{\tilde{p}}\phi(\theta))] in the form of HIP as ⟨ϕ,ϕ∗⟩ℋdsubscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑\langle\phi,\phi^{*}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}, where function ϕ∗​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼q​[∇log⁡p~​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]superscriptitalic-ϕ⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]∇~𝑝𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi^{*}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log\tilde{p}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)] and the update function ϕ​(⋅)italic-ϕ⋅\phi(\cdot) is restricted to zero-centered balls of a RKHS ℋdsuperscriptℋ𝑑\mathcal{H}^{d} defined by a kernel k​(θ,θ′)k𝜃superscript𝜃′\mathrm{k}(\theta,\theta^{\prime}), where the norm of the ball is taken to be ‖ϕ∗‖ℋd2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑2\|\phi^{*}\|_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}^{2}. Accordingly, the HIP can achieve the maximum value when the update function ϕ​(θ)italic-ϕ𝜃\phi(\theta) takes the same norm and direction as the function ϕ∗​(θ)superscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\phi^{*}(\theta) so that the gradient of the KL divergence can achieve the maximum value, which allows the particles to update towards the target distribution at the fastest speed. Therefore, SVGD takes ϕ​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼q​[∇log⁡p~​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]italic-ϕ⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]∇~𝑝𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log\tilde{p}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)] as the update function for the normalized distribution p​(θ)∝p~​(θ)proportional-to𝑝𝜃~𝑝𝜃p(\theta)\propto\tilde{p}(\theta) to update the set of particles {θn}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N}. The vartional distribution is obtained using a Kernel Density Estimator (KDE) over the particles as q​(θ)=∑n=1NK​(θ,θn)𝑞𝜃superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁𝐾𝜃subscript𝜃𝑛q(\theta)=\sum_{n=1}^{N}K(\theta,\theta_{n}) and by controlling the number of particles, SVGD can trade off the bias of the vartional distribution and the speed of convergence, providing flexible performance.

II-B3 Distributed Stein Variational Gradient Descent

DSVGD inherits the performance of SVGD in terms of bias, convergence speed, and per-iteration complexity by controlling the number of particles [23]. At each global iteration i=1,2,…,I𝑖12…𝐼i=1,2,\ldots,I, DSVGD maintains a set of global particles {θn(i−1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖1𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at the server side, which represent the approximate posterior q(i−1)​(θ)superscript𝑞𝑖1𝜃q^{(i-1)}(\theta) of the current model parameters, and a set of local particles {θn,k(i−1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑘𝑖1𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n,k}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at the client side, which represent the approximate scaled local likelihood tk(i−1)​(θ)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖1𝜃t_{k}^{(i-1)}(\theta). Both the global and local particles are updated using SVGD as follows: first, the global particles {θn(i−1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖1𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} are downloaded by the client k𝑘k and updated by running L𝐿L local SVGD iterations to approximate the local tilted distribution p~k(i)​(θ)superscriptsubscript~𝑝𝑘𝑖𝜃\tilde{p}_{k}^{(i)}(\theta) as

θn[l]←θn[l−1]←superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛delimited-[]𝑙superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛delimited-[]𝑙1\displaystyle\theta_{n}^{[l]}\leftarrow\theta_{n}^{[l-1]} +ϵN∑j=1N[k(θj[l−1],θn[l−1])∇θjlogp~k(i)(θj[l−1])\displaystyle+\frac{\epsilon}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}[\mathrm{k}(\theta_{j}^{[l-1]},\theta_{n}^{[l-1]})\nabla_{\theta_{j}}\log\tilde{p}_{k}^{(i)}(\theta_{j}^{[l-1]})
+∇θjk(θj[l−1],θn[l−1])],\displaystyle+\nabla_{\theta_{j}}\mathrm{k}(\theta_{j}^{[l-1]},\theta_{n}^{[l-1]})], (13)

for l=1,2,…,L𝑙12…𝐿l=1,2,\ldots,L and where the global approximate posterior is then obtained using a KDE of the global particles as q​(θ)=N−1​∑n=1NK​(θ,θn)𝑞𝜃superscript𝑁1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁K𝜃subscript𝜃𝑛q(\theta)=N^{-1}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\mathrm{K}(\theta,\theta_{n}). Similarly, the local particles are updated by running L′superscript𝐿′L^{\prime} local SVGD iterations to approximate the distribution tk(i)​(θ)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖𝜃t_{k}^{(i)}(\theta) as

θk,n[l′]←θk,n[l′−1]←superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑛delimited-[]superscript𝑙′superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑘𝑛delimited-[]superscript𝑙′1\displaystyle\theta_{k,n}^{[l^{\prime}]}\leftarrow\theta_{k,n}^{[l^{\prime}-1]} +ϵ′N∑j=1N[k(θk,j[l′−1],θk,n[l′−1])∇θjlogtk(i)(θ)\displaystyle+\frac{\epsilon^{\prime}}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}[\mathrm{k}(\theta_{k,j}^{[l^{\prime}-1]},\theta_{k,n}^{[l^{\prime}-1]})\nabla_{\theta_{j}}\log t_{k}^{(i)}(\theta)
+∇θjk(θk,j[l′−1],θk,n[l′−1])],\displaystyle+\nabla_{\theta_{j}}\mathrm{k}(\theta_{k,j}^{[l^{\prime}-1]},\theta_{k,n}^{[l^{\prime}-1]})], (14)

where tk(i)​(θ)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑖𝜃t_{k}^{(i)}(\theta) is computed using (7). To summarize, the process of DSVGD is as follows:

  • •

    Step 1: The server serially selects a client and sends the current global particles {θn(i−1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖1𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} to the selected client.

  • •

    Step 2: The selected client minimizes the local free energy in (5) by running SVGD algorithm (see (II-B3)) to obtain the current global particles {θn(i)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}^{(i)}\}_{n=1}^{N}.

  • •

    Step 3: The updated global particles {θn(i)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}^{(i)}\}_{n=1}^{N} are uploaded to the server and the local particles {θn,k(i−1)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑘𝑖1𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n,k}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N} are updated by running SVGD algorithm (see (II-B3)) to obtain the current local particles {θn,k(i)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑘𝑖𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n,k}^{(i)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at the client side.

  • •

    Step 4: The server updates the current global particles by setting {θn(i−1)}n=1N⟵{θn(i)}n=1N⟵superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖1𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑖𝑛1𝑁\{\theta_{n}^{(i-1)}\}_{n=1}^{N}\longleftarrow\{\theta_{n}^{(i)}\}_{n=1}^{N} and continues to serially select the next client.

In this paper, we consider the selection problem for DSVGD which aims to select the client that contributes most to the decrease of the global free energy in each global iteration and thus improving convergence.

III Client Selection Schemes for Federated Bayesian Learning

In this section, we start by introducing a generic client selection framework for DSVGD. Then, we propose two schemes, namely KSD-based scheme and HIP-based scheme. Moreover, we analyze the convergence of DSVGD which reveals that both schemes improve the model convergence, where the KSD-based scheme has smaller communication overhead and the HIP-based scheme has faster convergence.

III-A Generic Client Selection Framework

We now introduce the generic client selection framework for federated Bayesian learning where the server estimates the selection distribution Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k}, for k∈{1,2,…,K}𝑘12…𝐾k\in\{1,2,...,K\} which represents the probability of selecting client k𝑘k. At each global iteration i𝑖i, a client k∈{1,2,…,K}𝑘12…𝐾k\in\{1,2,...,K\} is selected based on the distribution Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} to update the global posterior. The step of this framework can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    Step 1 (Global Posterior Broadcast): The server broadcasts the current global posterior to all clients.

  • •

    Step 2 (Importance Indicator Report): Each client k𝑘k computes an indicator and reports the result to the server. This step is going to be detailed later.

  • •

    Step 3 (Selection Distribution Calculation): Based on the received reports, the server computes the selection distribution Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} of the clients.

  • •

    Step 4 (Client Selection): Based on the selection distribution, the server selects a client, and then solicits updates from the selected client.

  • •

    Step 5 (Global Posterior Update): The selected client minimizes local free energy in (5) to obtain the new global posterior.

  • •

    Step 6 (Global Posterior Upload and Approximate Scaled Local Likelihood Update): The selected client uploads the global posterior obtained in the previous step to the server and updates the approximate scaled local likelihood using (7).

Note that the client selection requires the addition of three steps: the importance indicator report (Step 2), selection distribution calculation (Step 3) and client selection (Step 4) to the traditional federated learning process presented in Sec. II-A. Also, the global posterior needs to be broadcast to all clients at the beginning of each communication iteration, instead of being sent serially to each client.

III-B KSD-Based Scheme

Federated Bayesian learning converges as the variational global posterior q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) gradually approximates each local tilted distribution (see (5)), where the discrepancy between each local tilted distribution and the current variational global posterior is different. Here, we measure this discrepancy in terms of KSD, which can be easily estimated from the local tilted distribution and the global particles representing the variational global posterior. A larger KSD between the two distributions indicates that the variational global posterior has not sufficiently approximated the local tilted distribution, and therefore the client may have contributed more to the decrease of the global free energy. A naive idea is to use KSD as an indicator for judging the importance of the client’s data, assigning the client with larger KSD value a higher probability of selection. We next analyse the convergence of the global free energy by stating the following lemma.

Lemma 1.

If a client k𝑘k is selected, from local iteration l𝑙l to l+1𝑙1l+1 during global iteration i𝑖i, the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy can be expressed as

(F​(q[l+1]​(θ))−F​(q[l]​(θ)))/α≤−ϵ​S​(q[l],p~k)𝐹superscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙1𝜃𝐹superscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙𝜃𝛼italic-ϵ𝑆superscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙subscript~𝑝𝑘\displaystyle\left(F(q^{[l+1]}(\theta))-F(q^{[l]}(\theta))\right)/\alpha\leq-\epsilon S(q^{[l]},\tilde{p}_{k})\leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\ \leavevmode\nobreak\
+2​(K−1)​lm​a​x(i)​2KL(q[l+1]∥q[l])\displaystyle+2(K-1)l_{max}^{(i)}\sqrt{2\mathrm{KL}(q^{[l+1]}\rVert q^{[l]})} , (15)

where lm​a​x(i)=supθmaxm≠k⁡|log⁡(tm(i−1)​(θ))⋅pm​(θ)|superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑚𝑎𝑥𝑖subscriptsupremum𝜃subscript𝑚𝑘⋅superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑚𝑖1𝜃subscript𝑝𝑚𝜃l_{max}^{(i)}=\sup_{\theta}\max_{m\neq k}\left|\log(t_{m}^{(i-1)}(\theta))\cdot p_{m}(\theta)\right|. As a corollary, after I𝐼I rounds,

(F​(q(I)​(θ))−F​(q(0)​(θ)))/α𝐹superscript𝑞𝐼𝜃𝐹superscript𝑞0𝜃𝛼\displaystyle\left(F(q^{(I)}(\theta))-F(q^{(0)}(\theta))\right)/\alpha
≤−ϵ​∑i=0I∑k=1KPk(i)​∑l=0L−1S​(q[l],p~k)absentitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿1𝑆superscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙subscript~𝑝𝑘\displaystyle\leq-\epsilon\sum_{i=0}^{I}\sum_{k=1}^{K}P_{k}^{(i)}\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}S(q^{[l]},\tilde{p}_{k})

where Pk(i)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑖P_{k}^{(i)} is the probability of selecting client k𝑘k in the i𝑖i-th iteration.

Proof.

See Appendix A. ∎

The first term on the right hand side of (1) corresponds to the upper bound of the decrease of the local free energy, expressed by the KSD between the local tilted distribution and the variational global posterior, while the second term of (1) corresponds to the upper bound of the impact of un-selected clients on the global free energy. Therefore, Lemma 1 shows that the decrease of the global free energy is influenced by both the selected clients and un-selected clients, where the selected client influences the decrease of global free energy through the decrease of the local free energy. It can be observed that the larger the client’s KSD is, the smaller the upper bound of the local free energy and the greater the contribution to the decrease of the local free energy. The idea is that the client with larger KSD will approximately reduce the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy while ignoring the effect of un-selected clients, and thus we use KSD to discriminate the importance of the client’s data, assigning a higher selection probability to the clients with larger KSD.

Definition 1.

The KSD-based selection distribution is defined as:

PKSD,k=Sk​(q,p~k)∑m=1KSm​(q,p~m).subscript𝑃KSD𝑘subscript𝑆𝑘𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑚𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑚\displaystyle P_{{\rm KSD},k}=\frac{S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}S_{m}(q,\tilde{p}_{m})}. (17)

Here we use the KSD between the variational global posterior q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) and the local tilted distribution p~k​(θ)subscript~𝑝𝑘𝜃\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta) as an indicator for judging the importance of the clients’ data. Intuitively, the client with a larger KSD can be prioritized based on the selection distribution in (17). More specifically, the server can prioritise the selection of clients whose local tilted distribution is not sufficiently approximated by the variational global posterior. We present the KSD-based scheme in Algorithm 1 where the step 4 to the step 6 correspond to the extra steps added by the selection framework with respect to the DSVGD algorithm.

Comparison to the round robin and random selection schemes: With the impact of un-selected clients approximately ignored, the KSD-based scheme results in a tighter upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy compared to the round robin and random selection schemes, where the probability of each client being selected is set uniformly to 1K1𝐾\frac{1}{K}. Specifically, defining ΔKSDsubscriptΔKSD\Delta_{\mathrm{KSD}} as the upper bound reduction from the KSD-based scheme compared to the round robin and random selection schemes, the bound of the KSD-based scheme is tighter if

ΔKSD=ϵ​∑k=1KSk​(q,p~k)​PKSD,k−ϵK​∑k=1KSk​(q,p~k)≥0,subscriptΔKSDitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝑃KSD𝑘italic-ϵ𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘0\displaystyle\Delta_{\mathrm{KSD}}=\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})P_{\mathrm{KSD},k}-\frac{\epsilon}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})\geq 0, (18)

which holds since

ϵ​∑k=1KSk​(q,p~k)italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘\displaystyle\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k}) PKSD,ksubscript𝑃KSD𝑘\displaystyle P_{\mathrm{KSD},k}
=\displaystyle= ϵ​∑k=1KSk​(q,p~k)2∑m=1KSm​(q,p~m)italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘superscript𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑚𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑚\displaystyle\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})^{2}}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}S_{m}(q,\tilde{p}_{m})}
≥\displaystyle\geq ϵK​∑k=1KSk​(q,p~k),(Jensen​Inequality)italic-ϵ𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑆𝑘𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘JensenInequality\displaystyle\frac{\epsilon}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}S_{k}(q,\tilde{p}_{k}),\quad\mathrm{(Jensen\leavevmode\nobreak\ Inequality)}

where the equality holds under the condition S1​(q,p~k)=S2​(q,p~k)=…=SK​(q,p~k)subscript𝑆1𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝑆2𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘…subscript𝑆𝐾𝑞subscript~𝑝𝑘S_{1}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})=S_{2}(q,\tilde{p}_{k})=...=S_{K}(q,\tilde{p}_{k}). In such a condition, the difference between each local tilted distribution and the current variational global posterior is the same, indicating that the clients’ data is IID. In this case, ΔKSD=0subscriptΔKSD0\Delta_{\mathrm{KSD}}=0 and the KSD-based scheme no longer improves the performance of the model.

III-C HIP-based Scheme

The KSD-based scheme proposed in the previous subsection exploits the divergence between distributions as an indicator of the importance of the clients’ data. However, this scheme actually only achieves the minimization of the decrease of the local free energy per iteration, as it ignores the impact of un-selected clients on the global free energy for simplicity. In this subsection, we integrate the impact of both the selected and un-selected clients (which corresponds to the first and second term on the right hand side in (1)) on the global free energy through the HIP between two SVGD update functions.

We start by recalling the update function for particles in SVGD. According to the previous discussion in Section II-B, the update function is restricted to a zero-centered ball of a RKHS ℋdsuperscriptℋ𝑑\mathcal{H}^{d} and is optimized to maximize the negative gradient of the KL divergence, which can be written in the form of the KSD as shown in (II-B2), and in turn can be further rewritten in the form of the HIP as ⟨ϕ,ϕ∗⟩ℋdsubscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑\langle\phi,\phi^{*}\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} as shown in (9), where ϕ∗​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼q​[∇log⁡p~k​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]superscriptitalic-ϕ⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]∇subscript~𝑝𝑘𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi^{*}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)] is referred to as the target update function for normalized distribution pk​(θ)∝p~k​(θ)proportional-tosubscript𝑝𝑘𝜃subscript~𝑝𝑘𝜃p_{k}(\theta)\propto\tilde{p}_{k}(\theta). When the update function ϕ​(θ)italic-ϕ𝜃\phi(\theta) is equal in size and direction to the target update function ϕ∗​(θ)superscriptitalic-ϕ𝜃\phi^{*}(\theta), the HIP can achieve a maximum value, when the norm of the ball is taken to be ‖ϕ∗‖ℋd2superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptℋ𝑑2\|\phi^{*}\|_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}^{2}. Similarly, when we choose a different update function, the difference in both the size and direction between it and the target update function in Hilbert space will cause the HIP to change, which in turn affects the speed at which the particles are updated towards the target distribution. Therefore, we can use the HIP between the update function ϕ​(θ)italic-ϕ𝜃\phi(\theta) and the target update function ϕ​(θ∗)italic-ϕsuperscript𝜃\phi(\theta^{*}) to measure the contribution of the particles update. A larger HIP indicates that the update function can make the variational distribution approach the target distribution at a faster speed, which makes a greater contribution to the particles update. This is formalized in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Given i.i.d. samples {θn}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑛1𝑁\left\{\theta_{n}\right\}_{n=1}^{N} drawn from the distribution q​(θ)𝑞𝜃q(\theta) and the score function Sp​1subscript𝑆𝑝1S_{p1} and Sp​2subscript𝑆𝑝2S_{p2}. We can estimate the HIP between the SVGD update function ϕ1​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼q​[∇log⁡p1​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]subscriptitalic-ϕ1⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]∇subscript𝑝1𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi_{1}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log p_{1}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)] for p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} and the SVGD update function ϕ2​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼q​[∇log⁡p2​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]subscriptitalic-ϕ2⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]∇subscript𝑝2𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi_{2}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log p_{2}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)] for p2subscript𝑝2p_{2} by using the properties of the RKHS. Define

hp1,p2​(θi,θj)subscriptℎsubscript𝑝1subscript𝑝2subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗\displaystyle h_{p_{1},p_{2}}(\theta_{i},\theta_{j}) =Sp1​(θi)T​k​(θi,θj)​Sp2​(θj)absentsubscript𝑆subscript𝑝1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑇ksubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗subscript𝑆subscript𝑝2subscript𝜃𝑗\displaystyle=S_{p_{1}}(\theta_{i})^{T}\mathrm{k}(\theta_{i},\theta_{j})S_{p_{2}}(\theta_{j})
+\displaystyle+ Sp1​(θi)T​∇θjk​(θi,θj)+∇θik​(θi,θj)T​Sp2​(θj)subscript𝑆subscript𝑝1superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑇subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑗ksubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗subscript∇subscript𝜃𝑖ksuperscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝜃𝑗𝑇subscript𝑆subscript𝑝2subscript𝜃𝑗\displaystyle S_{p_{1}}(\theta_{i})^{T}\nabla_{\theta_{j}}\mathrm{k}(\theta_{i},\theta_{j})+\nabla_{\theta_{i}}\mathrm{k}(\theta_{i},\theta_{j})^{T}S_{p_{2}}(\theta_{j})

(19)
Proof.

See Appendix B. ∎

Theorem 1 reveals that we can estimate the HIP between the SVGD update function for p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} and the target update function for target distribution p2subscript𝑝2p_{2} using (19), and thus use the HIP estimate to measure the contribution of the SVGD update function for p1subscript𝑝1p_{1} to the update of particles towards the target distribution p2subscript𝑝2p_{2}.

Lemma 2.

Given ⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} representing the HIP between the update functions for the likelihoods of client k𝑘k and client m𝑚m, the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy per iteration can be written as

(F(q[l+1](θ))−F(q[l](θ)))/\displaystyle\left(F(q^{[l+1]}(\theta))-F(q^{[l]}(\theta))\right)/ α≤𝛼absent\displaystyle\alpha\leq
−ϵ​∑m=1K⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋd+∑m=1Kitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾\displaystyle-\epsilon\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}+\sum_{m=1}^{K} KL(q[l]∥tm(i−1))+logC,\displaystyle\mathrm{KL}(q^{[l]}\rVert t_{m}^{(i-1)})+\log C, (20)

where C=∏m=1KCm𝐶superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝐾subscript𝐶𝑚C=\prod_{m=1}^{K}C_{m} is a normalization constant such that ∫tm​(θ)Ck​dθ=1subscript𝑡𝑚𝜃subscript𝐶𝑘differential-d𝜃1\int\frac{t_{m}(\theta)}{C_{k}}\mathrm{d}\theta=1 for m=1,…,K𝑚1…𝐾m=1,\ldots,K.

Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

Here in Lemma 2, and in contrast with Lemma 1, only the first term in the upper bound is related to the selected client, and thus, the second term and the third term can be ignored. The first term is written in the from of the HIP, which is the sum of HIP between the update functions of the selected client k𝑘k and all clients including both the selected and un-selected clients. Specifically, the HIP term can be divided into ⟨ϕk,ϕk⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{k}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} and ∑m≠k⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋdsubscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑\sum_{m\neq k}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}. The term ⟨ϕk,ϕk⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{k}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} can be rewritten in the form of KSD as S​(q,pk)𝑆𝑞subscript𝑝𝑘S(q,p_{k}), which represents the discrepancy between the local likelihood pksubscript𝑝𝑘p_{k} of the selected client k𝑘k and the variational global posterior q𝑞q represented by the global particles. In addition, the impact of an un-selected client m𝑚m is expressed as ⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}, which is the contribution of the SVGD update functions of the selected client k𝑘k to the update of particles towards the local likelihood pmsubscript𝑝𝑚p_{m} of un-selected client m𝑚m. Therefore, the term ∑m≠k⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋdsubscript𝑚𝑘subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑\sum_{m\neq k}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} manifest the impact of all un-selected clients by aggregating the contributions of the selected client k𝑘k that causes particles to update in different directions. Lemma 2 reveals that the larger the HIP term the smaller the upper bound on the decrease of the global free energy per iteration, indicating that the selected client can make a greater contribution to the decrease of the global free energy. We now state a lemma that will prove useful to further simplify the upper bound in lemma 2.

Lemma 3.

Given the distribution p′=(∏m=1Kpm)1Ksuperscript𝑝′superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑚1𝐾p^{\prime}=\left(\prod_{m=1}^{K}p_{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{K}} and the SVGD update function for p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} as ϕ′​(⋅)=𝔼θ∼q​[∇log⁡p′​(θ)​k​(θ,⋅)+∇k​(θ,⋅)]superscriptitalic-ϕ′⋅subscript𝔼similar-to𝜃𝑞delimited-[]∇superscript𝑝′𝜃k𝜃⋅∇k𝜃⋅\phi^{\prime}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}_{\theta\sim q}[\nabla\log p^{\prime}(\theta)\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)+\nabla\mathrm{k}(\theta,\cdot)], we can further rewrite the HIP term ∑m=1K⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋdsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} as

∑m=1K⟨ϕk,ϕm⟩ℋd=K⋅⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd.superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptℋ𝑑⋅𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\displaystyle\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi_{m}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}=K\cdot\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}. (21)
Proof.

See Appendix D. ∎

Lemma 3 transforms the sum of HIP into the HIP between the update function for the likelihood of client k𝑘k and the update function of the global averaged likelihood p′=(∏m=1Kpm)1Ksuperscript𝑝′superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑚1𝐾p^{\prime}=\left(\prod_{m=1}^{K}p_{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{K}}. According to the previous discussion, since p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} is a geometric average of the local likelihoods across K𝐾K clients, p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime} contains the likelihood information of all clients. Therefore, we define the global averaged likelihood as the target distribution, the sum of HIP in (2) represents the contribution of client k𝑘k to the update of the particles towards the global averaged likelihood, which contains information about all clients.

Theorem 2.

Using Lemma 3, we can further simplify the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy in (2) as

(F​(q[l+1]​(θ))−F​(q[l]​(θ)))/α≤𝐹superscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙1𝜃𝐹superscript𝑞delimited-[]𝑙𝜃𝛼absent\displaystyle\left(F(q^{[l+1]}(\theta))-F(q^{[l]}(\theta))\right)/\alpha\leq −ϵ​K⋅⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd⋅italic-ϵ𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\displaystyle-\epsilon K\cdot\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}
+∑m=1KKLsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾KL\displaystyle+\sum_{m=1}^{K}\mathrm{KL} (q[l]∥tm(i−1))+logC.\displaystyle(q^{[l]}\rVert t_{m}^{(i-1)})+\log C. (22)

As a corollary, after I𝐼I rounds,

(F​(q(I)​(θ))−F​(q(0)​(θ)))/α𝐹superscript𝑞𝐼𝜃𝐹superscript𝑞0𝜃𝛼\displaystyle\left(F(q^{(I)}(\theta))-F(q^{(0)}(\theta))\right)/\alpha
≤−ϵ​∑i=0I∑k=1KPk(i)​∑l=0L−1K⋅⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋdabsentitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑖0𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑙0𝐿1⋅𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\displaystyle\leq-\epsilon\sum_{i=0}^{I}\sum_{k=1}^{K}P_{k}^{(i)}\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}K\cdot\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}
+∑i=0I∑l=0L−1(∑m=1KKL(q[l]∥tm(i−1))+logC),\displaystyle\quad+\sum_{i=0}^{I}\sum_{l=0}^{L-1}\left(\sum_{m=1}^{K}\mathrm{KL}(q^{[l]}\rVert t_{m}^{(i-1)})+\log C\right), (23)

where Pk(i)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝑘𝑖P_{k}^{(i)} is the probability of selecting client k𝑘k in the i𝑖i-th iteration.

Here only the HIP term ⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} is relevant to the client selection. Theorem 2 reveals that the upper bound is smaller when the HIP term ⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} is larger, indicating that the client has a greater contribution to the global particles update if the client can get the particles to update towards the global averaged likelihood p′superscript𝑝′p^{\prime}, which contains information about all clients, at a faster speed. Therefore, we consider the HIP term ⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} as a measure of the importance of the clients’ data and assign higher selection probabilities to the clients with larger HIP.

Definition 2.

The HIP-based selection distribution is defined as:

PHIP,k=⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd∑m=1K⟨ϕm,ϕ′⟩ℋd.subscript𝑃HIP𝑘subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\displaystyle P_{{\rm HIP},k}=\frac{\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{m},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}}. (24)

Here we use the HIP between the update function for local likelihood and the update function for the global averaged likelihood p′=(∏m=1Kpm)1Ksuperscript𝑝′superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑚1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑚1𝐾p^{\prime}=\left(\prod_{m=1}^{K}p_{m}\right)^{\frac{1}{K}} as an indicator for judging the importance of a client’s data. Intuitively, using (24), the server can prioritize the client who updates particles towards the global averaged likelihood at a faster speed, maximizing the decrease of the global free energy per iteration. Finally, we present the HIP-based scheme in Algorithm 2 where the step 4 to the step 6 corresponds the extra steps with respect to DSVGD and are added for selecting.

Comparison to the round robin and random selection schemes: The HIP-based scheme results in a tighter upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy compared to the round robin and random selection schemes. Specifically, we define ΔHIPsubscriptΔHIP\Delta_{\mathrm{HIP}} as the upper bound reduction from the HIP-based scheme compared to the round robin and random selection schemes, the bound of the HIP-based scheme is tighter if

ΔHIP=ϵ​∑k=1K⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd​PHIP,k−ϵK​∑k=1K⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd≥0,subscriptΔHIPitalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑subscript𝑃HIP𝑘italic-ϵ𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑0\displaystyle\Delta_{\mathrm{HIP}}=\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}P_{\mathrm{HIP},k}-\frac{\epsilon}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}\geq 0, (25)

which holds since

ϵ​∑k=1K⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋditalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\displaystyle\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}} PHIP,ksubscript𝑃HIP𝑘\displaystyle P_{\mathrm{HIP},k}
=\displaystyle= ϵ​∑k=1K⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd2∑m=1K⟨ϕm,ϕ′⟩ℋditalic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑2superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑚superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\displaystyle\epsilon\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}^{2}}{\sum_{m=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{m},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}}
≥\displaystyle\geq ϵK​∑k=1K⟨ϕk,ϕ′⟩ℋd,(Jensen​Inequality)italic-ϵ𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑘superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑JensenInequality\displaystyle\frac{\epsilon}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left\langle\phi_{k},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}},\quad\mathrm{(Jensen\leavevmode\nobreak\ Inequality)}

where the equality holds under the condition ⟨ϕ1,ϕ′⟩ℋd=⟨ϕ2,ϕ′⟩ℋd=…=⟨ϕK,ϕ′⟩ℋdsubscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ1superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ2superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑…subscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝐾superscriptitalic-ϕ′superscriptℋ𝑑\left\langle\phi_{1},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}=\left\langle\phi_{2},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}=...=\left\langle\phi_{K},\phi^{\prime}\right\rangle_{\mathcal{H}^{d}}. In such a condition, the HIP between the local update function of each client and the global update function is the same, indicating that the clients’ data is IID. In this case, ΔHIP=0subscriptΔHIP0\Delta_{\mathrm{HIP}}=0 and the HIP-based scheme no longer improves the performance of the model.

IV Experimental Results

In this section, we conduct experiments to validate the theoretical analysis and test the performance of the proposed schemes.

IV-A Experiment Settings

As in [23] and [24], for all our experiments with SVGD and DSVGD, we use the Radial Basis Function (RBF) kernel k​(x,x0)=e​x​p​(−‖x−x0‖22/h)k𝑥subscript𝑥0𝑒𝑥𝑝superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑥subscript𝑥022ℎ\mathrm{k}(x,x_{0})=exp(-\|x-x_{0}\|_{2}^{2}/h) and take the bandwidth to be h=med2/log⁡nℎsuperscriptmed2𝑛h=\mathrm{med}^{2}/\log n where medmed\mathrm{med} is the median of the pairwise distance between the particles in the current iterate, so that the bandwidth hℎh changes according to the set of particles adaptively across the iterations. As for the KSD estimator, we use the Gaussian kernel K​(⋅,⋅)K⋅⋅\mathrm{K}(\cdot,\cdot) where the bandwidth is set to 0.55. We use AdaGrad for step size and initialize the particles using the prior distribution unless otherwise specified. Finally, we fix the temperature parameter α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 in (1) throughout the iterations.

For exposition, we consider the learning task of training classifiers. Two prevalent learning models of Bayesian logistic regression (BLR) [39] and Bayesian Neural Networks (BNN) [40] are employed for implementation. First, We consider BLR model for binary classification using the same setting as in [39]. The model parameters is define as θ=[𝐰,log⁡(ξ)]𝜃𝐰𝜉\theta=[\mathbf{w},\log(\xi)] where parameter ξ𝜉\xi is a precision and the regression weights 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} is assigned with a Gaussian prior p0​(𝐰|ξ)=𝒩​(𝐰|𝟎,ξ−1​𝐈d)subscript𝑝0conditional𝐰𝜉𝒩conditional𝐰0superscript𝜉1subscript𝐈𝑑p_{0}(\mathbf{w}|\xi)=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{w}|\mathbf{0},\xi^{-1}\mathbf{I}_{d}) and p0​(ξ)=Gamma​(ξ|1,0.01)subscript𝑝0𝜉Gammaconditional𝜉10.01p_{0}(\xi)=\mathrm{Gamma}(\xi|1,0.01). The local likelihood at each client k𝑘k is given as pk=∏xi,yi∈Dkp​(yi|xi,𝐰,ξ)subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptproductsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝐰𝜉p_{k}=\prod_{x_{i},y_{i}\in D_{k}}p(y_{i}|x_{i},\mathbf{w},\xi), where Dksubscript𝐷𝑘D_{k} is the dataset at client k𝑘k with covariates xk∈ℝdsubscript𝑥𝑘superscriptℝ𝑑x_{k}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and label yk∈{−1,1}subscript𝑦𝑘11y_{k}\in\{-1,1\}. Similarly, we consider multi-label classification with BNN model using the same setting as in [23]. The model parameters θ=[𝐖,log⁡(γ)]𝜃𝐖𝛾\theta=[\mathbf{W},\log(\gamma)] include a precision parameter γ𝛾\gamma along with the weights of neural network 𝐖𝐖\mathbf{W} assigned with a Gaussian prior p0​(𝐖|λ)=𝒩​(𝐖|𝟎,λ−1​𝐈d)subscript𝑝0conditional𝐖𝜆𝒩conditional𝐖0superscript𝜆1subscript𝐈𝑑p_{0}(\mathbf{W}|\lambda)=\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{W}|\mathbf{0},\lambda^{-1}\mathbf{I}_{d}) with a fixed precision λ=e𝜆𝑒\lambda=e. The data of client k𝑘k is given as Dk={xi,yi}i=1Ksubscript𝐷𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝐾D_{k}=\{x_{i},y_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K} and ynsubscript𝑦𝑛y_{n} is obtained as yn=f​(xn;𝐖)+nsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑓subscript𝑥𝑛𝐖𝑛y_{n}=f(x_{n};\mathbf{W})+n where the neural network output f​(⋅;𝐖)𝑓⋅𝐖f(\cdot;\mathbf{W}) is corrupted by additive noise variables n𝑛n, where n∼𝒩​(0,γ−1)similar-to𝑛𝒩0superscript𝛾1n\sim\mathcal{N}(0,\gamma^{-1}). The number of hidden layers containing 100 hidden units is set to one and RELU is set as the activation function. The local likelihood at each client k𝑘k is given as pk=∏xi,yi∈Dkp​(yi|xi,𝐖,γ)subscript𝑝𝑘subscriptproductsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘𝑝conditionalsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝐖𝛾p_{k}=\prod_{x_{i},y_{i}\in D_{k}}p(y_{i}|x_{i},\mathbf{W},\gamma).

To better simulate the data distribution, we consider the non-IID data partitioning way as follows. For the BLR model, we choose the Covertype dataset, which contains two types of labels y∈{−1,1}𝑦11y\in\{-1,1\}. We define the number of clients as 30 and 120, where the ratio of the two categories in each client’s data is 1:9. For the BNN model, we choose nine typical classes from digit “0” to “8” in the well-known dataset MNIST for classification and define the number of clients as 27 and 120, where each client owns only three types of dataset, making the data distribution over clients a pathological non-IID manner. Moreover, since a pathological non-IID distribution of clients data, we set the number of local iterations to 10 to ensure that the model converges.

To demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed selection schemes, we implement two baseline schemes in the following experiments, the round robin selection scheme and the random selection scheme. Specifically, the round robin selection scheme is used by the authors of [23] in DSVGD, which selects each client in a certain order, and the random selection scheme is the more common selection scheme in federated learning, where the server randomly selects a client at each iteration. In addition, since the communication load caused by HIP-based selection scheme is similar to that of the parallel DSVGD algorithm, we also conduct experiment to compare the model performance between the two schemes.

IV-B KSD-Based Selection Scheme

Fig. 2(a) and Fig. 2(b) depicts the learning performance of the KSD-based scheme compared with the two baseline schemes using the BLR model. From the figure, we can observe that the KSD-based scheme achieves the same model convergence speed as the round robin scheme at the early stage of model training, and both schemes converge faster than the random selection scheme. In the later stage of model training, the KSD-based scheme outperforms the other two schemes, where the random scheme has lower model accuracy and worse model convergence, and the model accuracy curve of the round robin scheme vibrates periodically and substantially making the model have no tendency to converge. Fig. 2(c) and Fig. 2(d) illustrates the performance comparison among the three schemes using the BNN model. It can be observed that the model performance of the random selection scheme is the worst, and its model accuracy and convergence are inferior to the other two schemes, while the model performance of the KSD-based scheme is better than that of the round robin scheme. Specifically, with the KSD-based scheme, the convergence curve is more stable than that of the round robin scheme throughout the model training process. These two experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the KSD-based scheme, which achieves the maximization of the decrease of the local free energy.

IV-C HIP-Based Scheme

From Fig. 3, we observe the better performance of HIP-based scheme compared to that of two baseline schemes using the BLR model and BNN model. Specifically, with HIP-based scheme, the model accuracy curve is always stable than that of two baseline schemes and the model accuracy is almost always higher than that of two baseline schemes, which especially significant in late iterations, demonstrating that the HIP-based scheme, which aims at minimizing the upper bound of the decrease of the global free energy, significantly improves the model performance in an environment with a pathological non-IID client data distribution, although the scheme causes more communication resources per iteration.

IV-D Comparison of the Two Proposed Schemes

We compare the model performance of the two proposed schemes in the BLR model and the BNN model. From Fig. 4, we observed that the performance of the HIP-based scheme is better, specifically, the convergence curve of the HIP-based scheme is more stable, while the convergence speed of the HIP-based scheme is slightly faster in the BNN model. This is consistent with the previous theoretical analysis that the KSD-based scheme considered only maximizing the decrease of the local free energy, while the HIP-based scheme maximizes the decrease of the global free energy and thus should exhibit better model performance.

IV-E Comparison with the Parallel DSVGD Algorithm

Fig. 5 depicts the performance of the HIP-based scheme compared with the parallel DSVGD algorithm using the BNN model. From this figure, we can observe that the convergence curve of the parallel DSVGD algorithm is more stable than that of the the HIP-based scheme, which is because the parallel DSVGD algorithm can use the likelihood information of all clients when updating the global particles, so that the global posterior does not favor a certain local likelihood. However, as the training proceeds, the model accuracy of the HIP-based scheme is asymptotically higher than that of the parallel DSVGD algorithm. The reason is that in the parallel DSVGD algorithm, there is an error in the KDE of the local particles uploaded at the client side, which does not accurately represent the information of the approximate scaled local likelihood, thus causing the loss of client data information in this step and degrading the accuracy of the model.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we proposed two client selection schemes for federated Bayesian learning, namely the KSD-based scheme and the HIP-based scheme. Through convergence analysis, we found that the KSD-based scheme maximizes the decrease of the local free energy per iteration and the HIP-based scheme improves the model convergence by maximizing the decrease of the global free energy per iteration. Comprehensive experiments using real datasets confirmed the performance gain of the proposed schemes compared with the baseline schemes.

-A Proof of Lemma 1

The decrease of the global free energy per iteration can be written as
